[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]] | occupation = [[Singer-songwriter]], [[List of harmonicists|harmonicist]] | years_active = Late 1950s–2000 | label = [[St. George Records|St. George]], Wolf Records, various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Little Mack Simmons''' (January 25, 1933 — October 24, 2000){{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/little-mack-simmons-mn0000835488/biography |title=Little Mack Simmons | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} was an [[African-American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[harmonica]] player, [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. ==Biography== '''Malcolm Simmons''' was born in [[Twist, Arkansas|Twist]], [[Arkansas]].{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 166–167 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} In his youth he befriended [[James Cotton]], and they grew up learning to play the harmonica. Simmons relocated to [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], at the age of 18 and worked on the [[Rail transport|railroad]]. At this time Simmons made his stage debut with [[Robert Lee McCollum|Robert Nighthawk]]. In 1954 he moved again to [[Chicago]], put together his own backing [[musical ensemble|band]], and had a five year residency at Cadillac Baby's. He commenced [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] in 1959, issuing [[Gramophone record|records]] on a number of [[record label|labels]] including [[Chess Records|Chess]]. In the late 1950s and early 1960s Simmons recorded several more obscure [[single (music)|singles]], often simply billed as Little Mack (or Mac). Simmons went on to provide the opportunity for others talents to be seen. He owned and managed Chicago's Zodiac Lounge from the mid to late 1960s. In addition, he owned a [[recording studio]] and recorded on his own labels, PM Records and Simmons Records. Simmons left the [[music industry]] at that time for the [[Minister (Christianity)|ministry]], and was rarely heard in 30 years, notwithstanding an [[album]] he recorded in 1975 in [[Paris]], [[France]]. His return to blues music arrived with ''High & Lonesome'' (1995), which was an early success for [[St. George Records]], an [[independent record label]]. Simmons' energetic style, accompanied by [[Studebaker John]], belied his years. ''Come Back to Me Baby'' (1996), with featured [[sideman|sidemen]] [[John Primer]], [[Willie Kent]] and Jake Dawson ([[guitarist]]) was also well received. Simmons died in October 2000, of [[colorectal cancer|colon cancer]], in his adopted hometown of Chicago, at the age of 67.{{cite web|author=
